Today she is still selling fabrics for national dresses at the famous market in her city. Malohat has about $2,000 invested in merchandise, and her net profit is about $300 each month. Her affordable pricing policy causes good turnover of her inventory and brings Malohat high profits.

Malohat is seeking an $800 loan to increase her turnover and sales rates. Malohat started this business when she couldn't find any other way to support herself and her family, so this venture is just like her baby, and she is very excited to see it expand and become sustainable. Malohat is hoping to make good money in business and eventually do some repairs to her family's house.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war that ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R. further damaged its already weak economy. 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable--conditions that have resulted in high levels of unemployment and forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase new fabrics to increase the range of goods for sale

loans.name: Yessika Waleska

texts.es:
la joven Jessica C. tiene 23 años de edad y reside en el barrrio buenos aires de la ciudad de san lorenzo, esta casada y espera a su primer hijo, ella tiene una pulperia que heredo de su madre, este negocio lo posee desde hace 5 años .
su madre le esta ayudando con el negocio ya que no tiene quien le ayude cuando ella necesita descazar por su embarazo.
su sueño es que su hijo que lleva dentro salga bien en su parto y que sea un hombre de bien.
a ella le gusta mucho ver telenovelas.
texts.en:
Jessica C. is a young twenty-three-year-old woman who lives in the neighborhood of Buenos Aires in the city of San Lorenzo. She is married and expecting her first child. She owns a small grocery store which she inherited from her mother and has had for five years. Her mother is helping her with the business, as she has no one else to help her when she needs to rest from her pregancy. Her dream is that the child she bears is born healthy and becomes a good man. She likes to watch soap operas very much.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia Cortina, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of soap, bread, crackers, batteries, bleach, soups, churros, sodas, dairy products, razors, toilet paper, beans, sugar, rice, lard, margarine, oil, cotton, pills, etc.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa A. is 47 years old. She is a married mother of five children. Currently, three of her children are in school, in senior high and junior high. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Nkawkaw in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Her husband is a farmer. Adwoa works to make some income to support her husband financially in providing for the family.

Adwoa trades in food items such as tin tomatoes, fish, rice, pepper, etc., on a tabletop in the market square. She procures her products from wholesalers in the nearby towns at cost-effective prices. Adwoa sells the products mostly to food vendors in her community. She has been in business for 10 years.

She wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to maximize her profit margin. Adwoa aspires to improve upon her living standard and to support her children’s education.

loans.use: To procure food items

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is known in her village as a responsible mother. She works as a fish vendor where she roams around the place using her tribike (also known as pedicab or a bike with three wheels).  Sometimes, her customers personally come to her house and buy fish. Her business has been a great help in sending their youngest child to school.  For the continuous improvement of her business and increased income, Marissa would like to borrow at least PHP 5,000.00, which will be used to purchase fish from a wholesale supplier in the market. She will retail it per kilo in the village to gain more income. 

Marissa is married and they have two children. The eldest is already married and works as a feed vendor while their youngest is still studying.  Her husband, Esteban, works in a barbershop in Manila, but despite the distance, they are both sacrificing to support the education of their child.  Her dreams are to have a permanent stall for her business, a bigger and concrete house, and for her child to earn a college diploma.  By simply being patient and working hard, Marissa believes that those dreams will turn to reality.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is married to a tricycle (three-wheeled vehicle) driver named Dante F.. They are blessed with four children who are all currently studying in their village. The couple lives with their children in a simple way of life in the rural village of Dumon Quezon, Isabela. Lydia and her family are helping each other for the progress of their livelihood. She and her husband are both hard-working and very patient to be able to have a better future.

Lydia and her husband have a business of tricycle transport in their village. And they don’t have enough funds for maintaining their business, that’s why she is requesting to take out a loan from ASKI amounting to PHP15,000 for the maintenance of their tricycle transport business.

According to Lydia, they were not able to cover all their family’s necessities, and for this reason, some of the loan will be used to start a small vending business to have additional income. She is hoping that through the help of the lenders, they will be able to earn more profit.

loans.use: additional working capital

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.en:
Bernardo C. owns a boat. He uses it for transportation service. People hire him to bring them to the neighboring islands or to the mainland. Bernardo is the 49-year-old father of 2 children. His wife, Diosdada C., is very supportive of him and his business.

While he takes care of their livelihood, his wife takes good care of their children. He needs a loan of Php 4,000 to repair his boat. Repair will cost a big amount and what he has is not enough to pay for the repair without the loan to add to his savings.

CEVI reaches out to a lot of poor communities to allow people to start up and run their own business. CEVI provides not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To repair his boat

loans.name: Pricilla

texts.en:
Pricilla E. is from the village of Purok Rizal, Bacolod, Ozamiz city. She is 49 years old. Pricilla is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Pricilla raises pigs. Pricilla has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately PHP 8000 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Pricilla joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Pricilla has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP 9000 from GDMPC. Pricilla is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which she will use to purchase feed for the piggery. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Pricilla from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to sustain the basic needs of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed for pigs.

loans.name: Nitzi Mariella

texts.es:
La señora Nitzi Mariella, pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Marginal II”, Distrito Banda de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 22 años y no tiene hijos.

Nitzi, se dedica a la Venta de Artesanía, nos cuenta que sus ventas le van muy bien y su negocio se encuentra en el local de Feria Artesanal, ubicado en el Centro de la Ciudad y para iniciarse mas a fondo en este negocio, decidió sacar un primer crédito de S/. 300.00,con esto poco a poco fue implementando su negocio y haciéndose conocida.

En la Actualidad continua con el mismo negocio y ahora ya tiene una clientela fija que mes a mes realizan sus pedidos o compras, ya que ella trabaja así y sus principales clientes son turistas, amigos y familiares, le va muy bien y mensualmente genera sus propios ingresos, y con el carisma que tiene sus ventas lo tiene asegurada. 

Con el préstamo de S/ 1,500.00, desea invertirlo comprando artesanías al por mayor confeccionadas a base de barro como: tinajitas, adornos de diferentes culturas; y otros de semillas y productos propio de la región como: aretes, pulseras, collares. Parte del dinero también lo invertirá comprando ropas, y juguetes tanto para niños y niñas. 

Nitzi Mariella, se siente muy contenta por lo logrado, feliz por que en su negocio le va muy bien. Esta muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla en iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Nitzi Mariella belongs to the La Marginal II Community Bank in the Banda de Tarapoto district, San Martín province, San Martín department. She is 22, single, and she does not have children. Nitzi sells handicrafts. Her sales are going very well. Her business is located in the Handicrafts Fair, which in the center of the city. She decided to take a loan for 300 PEN to really start the business. Little by little she has been establishing her business and becoming known. She currently continues with the same business. She now has a client base that makes monthly orders or purchases. Her primary customers are tourists, friends, and family. It is going very well. She generates her own monthly income. With the charisma she has, she is assured of sales. With the loan for 1,500 PEN she wants to make wholesale purchases of clay handicrafts such as large earthen jars and decorations from different cultures. She also wants to buy handicrafts made from seeds and products from her own region such as earrings, bracelets, and necklaces. She will use part of the money to buy clothes and toys for boys and girls. Nitzi Mariella feels very happy for what she has achieved. She is happy because her business is going very well. She is very grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for helping her start her business and for helping so many women who want to grow entrepreneurially.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy handicrafts made from clay and seeds

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin is a LAPO client. She sells kerosene in retail and wholesale to her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more kerosene to sell. Toyin is 47 years old and married with three children. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Tola

texts.en: Tola O. is 34 years old and married with 4 children. She sells crates of eggs. She is requesting a loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more crates of eggs to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Ilem B Group

texts.en:
Yusta is a member of the Ilem B borrower group in Mwanjelwa,Mbeya,she is 24 years old woman,she is widowed and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 3 and 1 years.

Yusta started her own shop business selling rice,sugar,salts 3 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Yusta`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more shop commodities.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Yusta hopes to save money and expand her business.

Bahati is another member of the same borrower group,she also requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities like rice,sugar for her shop

loans.name: Cesar Paulino

texts.es:
La actividad a la que se dedica el señor Cesar T. es a la ganadería o sector pecuario en el municipio de Telica del departamento de León. Es de importancia destacar que el señor Cesar es el responsable de mantener su hogar y llevar el sustento a sus dos hijos pequeños.

Es por este motivo que require invertir en la compra de vacas para proceder con su crianza y sacarle el máximo provecho extrayéndole la leche y así comercializarla en su comunidad. Para esto espera en que el crédito de Ceprodel le sea otorgado satisfactoriamente y continuar con su obra.

loans.use: Compra de vaca

loans.name: Laker

texts.en:
Laker E. is 35 years old and married to a businessman. She has four children who are currently in school. Laker is in the business of selling bread and cooking oil, and is requesting a loan to purchase more jerrycans of cooking oil to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, Laker hopes to be able to open up a shop.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more jerrycans of cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Isabel Cristina

texts.es: La Señora Isabel Hernández tiene 55 años de edad, madre soltera con tres hijos no son independiente lo tiene estudiando. Los proyectos que tiene son darle a sus hijos un mejor provenir por medio su trabajo. Doña Isabel tiene un trabajo de medio tiempo como cocinera en una casa y tiene su negocio de ventas de ropas desde hace un año, las dificultades el bajo ingreso para la compra de productos. Gracias  A Afodenic por el préstamo el cual lo invertirá en la comprar de productos como: ropa para damas, perfumes, zapatos, ropas interior y cosméticos teniendo una variedad de productos y obteniendo mayor utilidades.
texts.en:
Mrs. Isabel Hernández is a 55-year-old single mother with three minor children who are all in school. She works to give her children a better future. Mrs. Isabel works part time as a home cook and also has had a clothing business for the past year. Her low income makes it difficult to buy merchandise. She is grateful to Afodenic (Kiva field partner) for the loan which she will use to buy products such as women's clothing, perfumes, shoes, underwear, and cosmetics. Having a variety of products will allow her to earn higher profits.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy clothing, perfume, and shoes

loans.name: Maria Beatriz

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Nueva Semilla se formó en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad se  caracteriza por los cuatro ríos que la bañan, los hábiles artesanos y su suculenta gastronomía atrae a turistas nacionales y extranjeros.

El Bankito Nueva Semilla está conformado por un grupo de mujeres que tienen como objetivo la superación  propia y de su familia mediante la capacitación y su inserción en el desarrollo de  la micro empresa para mejorar su situación económica y su calidad de vida.

La señora María Beatriz  A. J. es una de las socias activas del  Banco Comunal Nueva Semilla, vive en la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca tiene 32 años de edad es casada y madre de dos niños de 8 y 4 años, su hija mayor estudia en la escuela Luisa de Jesús Cordero, viven en casa de su mamá en un departamento independiente, su esposo trabaja en la construcción por  lo que no tiene muchos ingresos.

María  tiene un pequeño bazar y papeleria desde hace dos años en casa de su madre y como no paga arriendo le ha permitido ir incrementado con cabinas telefónicas y con la venta de todo tipo de videos.

Ella lleva  un año y medio trabajando en la banca comunal y nos manifiesta que los créditos obtenidos los ha invertido en la implementación de las cabinas telefónicas y la adquisición  de videos,  con el préstamo que la FUNDACIÓN ESPOIR le entregue  va a invertir en la compra de artículos de bazar como  regalos, perfumes, vajillas, adornos y papelería como cuadernos, pinturas, marcadores y la lista de útiles escolares para sus hijos.

Su sueño es llegar a tener su propia casa y también un auto.
texts.en:
The “Nueva Semilla” (New Seed) Communal Bank began in the city of Cuenca. This city is known for the four rivers that flow through it, its' skillful artists and its' gastronomic delights that attract both national and international tourists. “Nueva Semilla” is made up of a group of women dedicated to training in the development of small businesses in order to improve their economic situation and the quality of their lives. Mrs. María Beatriz A. J. is one of the active members of the communal bank “Nueva Semilla”. She lives in the city of Cuenca. She is a 32 year old, married mother of two children, 8 and 4 years old. Her oldest daughter studies at the Luisa de Jesús Cordero School. The family lives in a private apartment within her mother’s house. Her husband works in construction and does not have a large income. For the past two years, María has a run a small bazaar and stationary store out of her mother’s house. Because she does not pay rent, she has been able to grow her business by adding in telephone booths and video sales. She has been working with the communal bank for a year and a half. The loans that she has obtained have been clearly used to bring in the telephone booths and acquire videos to sell. With the loan from the FUNDACIÓN ESPOIR she will buy small articles to sell in her bazaar such as gifts, perfumes, tableware, ornaments, notebooks, paints, markers and the list of school supplies for her children. Her dreams is to own her own house and also a car.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy small articles to sell in her store

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary E. sells baked bread at Essuman near Shama Junction. Mary has received a senior high school education. She is married and has four children. Mary has been selling baked bread since 2000. She asists her husband in the paying of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more flour and other baking ingredients to improve and increase her baking business. She hopes to save the new profits to invest in her business.

loans.use: Buy more flour and other baking ingredients to improve and increase her baking business.

loans.name: Celia Argentina

texts.es: La señora Celia Argentina S., cumplió 51 años,   desde hace veinte años se dedica a prestar sus servicios en el ramo de la belleza adomicilio , la mayor dificultad que se le presenta es que a pesar que trabaje día completo no tiene los recursos económicos necesarios para poder terminar de construir su vivienda ,con el financiamiento quiere comprar materia les de construcción como: arena, cemento,   ya que si logra terminarla en un futuro quiere poner su propio salón de belleza y poder estar mas al pendiente de sus hijos , por que cuando sale a trabajar tiene que pagar para que alguien le cuide a su hijos de cuatro años, doña Celia es madre soltera , el apoyo que recibe es sus dos hijos mayores que trabajan y estudian.
texts.en:
Celia Argentina S., 51, has been a beautician for the past 20 years. She goes door-to-door to attend to her customers. The greatest difficulty she has is that, despite working the entire day, she still does not have enough funds to be able to finish building her house. With the funds requested, she plans to buy building materials like sand and cement because, if she manages to finish it, her plan is to set up her beauty salon in her house so that she can be more watchful of her children because, presently, when she goes out to work she has to hire someone to look after her four children. Cecilia is a single mother and the little help she gets comes from her two oldest sons who work and study.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sand and cement to finish building her house.

loans.name: Jeanny Marivil

texts.es:
La socia JEANNY MARIVIL hace un año que pertenece al banco comunal “PROSPERIDAD”  

Nuestra socia es una joven madre de familia, tiene 28 años de edad, es casada, tienen dos hijos y esta embarazada. Ellos viven en la ciudad imperial del Cusco. 

La socia alterna sus actividades con el pequeño negocio de venta de comestibles. Ella tiene una tienda en su domicilio donde ofrece los productos a sus vecinos. Ya son varios años que trabaja en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio comprando más comestibles como arroz, azúcar, fideos y verduras.  
  
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Jeanny Marivil is a member of the communal bank "Prosperidad." She is a young mother who is 28 years old and married. She has 2 children and is expecting a third; they live in the city of Cusco. Jeanny alternates her activities in the home with a small business selling foodstuffs. She has a store in her house where she offers products to her neighbors. She has already worked in this business for a number of years and it has gone very well thanks to all of the effort she has put into the work. She is an enterprising mother who works hard to advance her family. She needs a loan to increase her business capital so that she can buy more foodstuffs such as rice, sugar, noodles and vegetables. She is grateful for the opportunity provided through these means, and she pledges to make her payments according to the established schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy food such as rice, sugar, noodles and vegetables for her store

loans.name: Evgeniya

texts.en:
Evgenia is married and has two adult children. She owns a retail business that sells various kinds of cosmetic. Her business is located at a small store that she rents at the central market.  Evgenia has been in this business for 11 years. She used to work as sales person. When she lost her job she decided to use her experience and start her own business. 

Today Evgenia has a large business location with electricity inside that helps her to prevent her inventory from freezing. Evgenia would like to borrow 18,129 UAH to purchase gift sets to sell during Christmas and New Year. She hopes to earn additional income and help her children and their families financially.

loans.use: to purchase gift sets for resale

loans.name: Neary's Group

texts.en:
This group loan is led by Mrs. Neary K.. The group consists of three people who live in Chrouy Dang Village in Kandal Province. Mrs. Neary K. and her husband, Mr. Sengtong Bun, are vegetable sellers who can make a small income for supporting their family. Now, Mrs. Neary K. wants to expand her business, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to re-sell for an income.

Mrs. Neary K. is 44 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is a fisherman and the other one makes fishnets for selling. Mrs. Ton Ny, who is a group guarantee, is also shown in the picture with the group members.

loans.use: To buy more vegetable to re-sell for an income

loans.name: Edwina

texts.en:
Edwina D. C. is a 36-year-old, hardworking mother who loves her three children. Her husband, Diosdado, is 40 years old and is a driver.

To help to sustain her family, Edwina started a business providing manicure and pedicure services and also food vending. She is applying for a new loan of Php 10,000 to buy a manicure set and the remaining money will be used for her food-vending business. 

In the future, Edwina hopes to establish her own canteen (outdoor cafe) where she can give better service to her regular customers. She also wants to be able to save for her children's education and to have a comfortable house to live in and a happy family to live with.

loans.use: To buy a manicure set and to use for her food vending business

loans.name: Karla Tatiana

texts.es:
Karla Tatiana V. R. es una señora de 31 años de edad la  cual vive con su esposo y sus cuatro hijos en una comunidad llamada Caño Negro localizada en Los Chiles, provincia de Alajuela; está comunidad se destaca por ser una zona montañosa y por estar muy cerca de la frontera norte de nuestro país. Sus principales actividades económicas son la ganadería y la agricultura específicamente se da la siembra de granos básicos, caña de azúcar, naranja.

Desde hace poco más de 2 meses que doña Karla trabaja en un hotel, dice que ahora tiene una fuente de ingreso con la cual ayudar  a su esposo con los gastos de su hogar  pero comenta que su trabajo se encuentra bastante lejos de su casa y que se le ha dificultado  la manera de llegar hasta él, ya que hay muy poco transporte público y su horario es rotativo por lo que a veces debe esperar mucho tiempo para encontrar transporte.

Por lo tanto doña Karla ha decidido comprar una moto para poder transportarse mejor y así agilizar  la forma en la que viaja con esto podrá  ahorrar y aprovechar más  el tiempo. Por lo cual requiere un préstamo de ¢654.000 (seiscientos cincuenta y cuatro mil colones) para comprar la moto y así poder tener un vehículo propio que le permita seguir adelante  y facilitarle su modo de viajar.

Doña Karla forma parte de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Emcrecoba, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su segundo préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico, además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Karla Tatiana V. R., 31, lives with her husband and their four children in a community called Caño Negro. It is located in Los Chiles in the Alajuela province. This area is in a mountainous region near the northern border of the country. The main economic activities are livestock breeding and agriculture, specifically the planting and harvesting of basic grains, sugar cane, and oranges. Karla has worked in a hotel for a little over two months. She says that she now has a source of income, which helps her husband with the household expenses. But, she says, her work is pretty far from her house. It is difficult for her to get there because there is very little public transportation and her schedule rotates. Sometimes she needs to wait a long time to find transportation. Therefore, Karla has decided to buy a motorcycle to be better able to get places. That way she will speed up the way she travels, and she will be able to save and take advantage of having more time. To do this she needs a loan for ¢654,000 (six hundred fifty four thousand colones) to buy the motorcycle. That way she will be able to have her own vehicle, which will allow her to get ahead and facilitate her form of travel. Karla is part of the Emcrecoba Communal Finance Institution, one the 100 organizations that are members of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her second loan, and with the loan she hopes to continue growing on a personal and economic level. She also plans on actively participating in the loan organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de una motocicleta

loans.name: Maria Margarita

texts.es:
La actividad principal a la que se dedica la Sra. María C. es la elaboración y venta de tortillas de Maíz, actividad a la cual se dedica desde hace siete años. Según va pasando el tiempo su negocio sigue en crecimiento; actualmente esta moliendo 14 medidas de Maíz diario, su negocio ya posee una empleada permanente a la cual le paga según la producción que elabora. 
Doña María vende sus tortillas a una sola persona y esta otra señora las vende en un puesto que tiene el mercado municipal de esta ciudad.
Doña María le hace entrega de las tortillas diario pero le cancelan los fines de semana y para moler esta cantidad de maíz ella nos comento que se levanta a las 2:00 a.m.
Doña Maria es una persona muy trabajadora y de reconocida solvencia moral, pero en la actualidad ella no cuenta con el capital de trabajo suficiente para la compra de maíz y también tiene un proyecto de construir una pieza mas de su casa pero que por los momentos solo va comprar los materiales para después construir y aprovechar en esta época los precios que estan mas bajos de lo normal,  y ella quiere tenerlos ya comprados.
texts.en:
The main work that Mrs. Maria C. does is making and selling corn tortillas. She has been doing this for the past seven years. As time passes, her business has grown and she is currently grinding 14 lots of corn every day. She has a permanent employee whom she pays according to how much she produces. Maria sells her tortillas to one person and this lady sells them in a stand that she has in the main market of this city. Maria delivers the tortillas every day but not on weekends. She tells us that to grind this quantity of corn, she needs to get up at 2:00 am. Maria is a hard-working woman and well-known for her reliability and morality. She tells us that now she doesn’t have enough working capital to buy corn, and also she has a project of building one more room in her house. At this time she wants to buy the construction materials to build later on. She would like to take advantage of this period when prices are lower than normal, and have the materials bought.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials and corn

loans.name: La Amistad Group

texts.es:
El comité La Amistad del barrio Yka´a de la Fracción Las Abellanas de la ciudad de Luque, se formó gracias a que señoras de otro grupo de un barrio vecino, quien aprovecharon y se acesoran sobre el programa de la Fundación en cuanto al  comité de mujeres e invitaron a que formaran un nuevo comité en esa zona. 
De esta forma se inicia el comité La Amistad, actualmente el comité se encuentra en el décimo segundo ciclo del Programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya y está conformado por 17 integrantes que invierten en distintas actividades.
Una de ellas es la señora Elva A.  quien tiene una despensa donde vende  todo tipo de artículos para la casa, de librería, para limpieza entre otros, su negocio es muy completo, y toda la familia ayuda de alguna manera para mantener y contar siempre con los ingresos del mismo ya que es fundamental por que de ella dependen todos los gastos de la casa y de los estudios de los hijos de la señora Elva.  El crédito que solicito lo invirtió en la compra de artículos que  faltaba en el negocio, de esa forma siempre cumple con sus clientes.
texts.en:
The La Amistad group, in the Yka´a community in the Fracción Las Avellanas neighborhood of Luque, Paraguay, formed when women from a group in another neighborhood heard about the foundation's program for women's groups and invited the members of La Amistad to establish a new group in that area. That's how the La Amistad group was formed. It's now in its 12th cycle with the Programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras with the Fundación Paraguaya, and has 17 members engaged in different businesses. One of the members is Elva A., who has a shop where she sells all kinds of household goods, office supplies, cleaning products, etc. She has a little of everything, and the whole family helps in some way to keep it going and be able to count on that income. The business is essential, since Elva is responsible for all the household expenses and her children's educations. She will use the requested loan to buy some products for her business so she can always fulfill her customers' requests.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy vegetables, oil, flour, soft drinks, beer, baked goods, meats, fruits, charcoal, cloth, thread, yeast

loans.name: Johana Lorena

texts.es:
Johana tiene 22 años, y vive en casa de su suegra hace 3 años aproximadamente ya que 
convivía con el padre de su menor hija; actualmente se encuentra separada de él sin 
embargo a pesar de ello recibe el apoyo de sus suegros en cuanto a vivienda y 
alimentación. Ella tiene un carrito sanguchero en el cual se dedica a vender 
hamburguesas todas las noches en la puerta de su casa. Requiere el crédito para 
incrementar y diversificar sus productos, ya que desea que su negocio se desarrolle y 
poder ser una persona totalmente independiente para  poderle brindar bienestar y una buena 
educación a su menor hija.
texts.en:
Johana, 22, has lived with her in-laws for the past three years because she was together with the father of her daughter. She is currently separated from him but, despite that, her in-laws continue to help out providing her with housing and food. She has a small food preparation cart that she uses to make hamburgers every night at her doorstep. She needs funds to increase and diversify her products because she hopes that her business will grow so that she can become completely independent and be able to provide for her daughter's wellbeing as well as for her education.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients and supplies.

loans.name: Hida

texts.es:
Hida es socia del Banco Comunal Universo.
Hida es casada, tiene 28 años y 3 hijos, Hida viaja a los diferentes pueblos de la región en donde compra papa, producto que vende en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Hida necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de papa.
Hida sueña con que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Hida is an associate of the Universe Communal Bank. Hida is married, 28 years old and has 3 children. Hida travels to the different villages of the region where she buys potatoes, a product that she sells in the supplies market of the city of Ayacucho. She performs this activity every day. Hida needs a loan of 1000 soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of potatoes. Hida dreams that her children will become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy potatoes for resale

loans.name: Selesa

texts.en:
Selesa Siaana I. is 30 and married with 3 children (ages 2 - 11).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting bananas for sale.  Selesa has 2 years of experience in this business.  Selesa needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase general farm supplies & equipment.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 280 talas or US $117 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Selesa joined SPBD.  This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Selesa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Natalia

texts.es: La Sra. Natalia es una cliente antigua y muy puntual D. la institución, se dedica a la venta D. leche, vive en la comunidad D. Chicani donD. tiene sus vacas lecheras, esta leche la venD. a una industria D. Bolivia muy conocida, en todo el país, tiene una hijita pequeña, su esposo se fue a trabajar al Brasil D. donD. le manda cada mes un dinero para los gastos D. la casa, pero no le alcanza asi  que ella debe dedicarse a esta actividad para ayudar con los gastos del hogar. El crédito será invertido para construcción D. un muro en su casita y asi poder vivir comodamente y brindar una buena calidad D. vida a su familia. Esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Sra. Natalia is a long-time client of Emprender who has been very prompt with her payments. She sells milk in the community of Chicani where she has dairy cows. The milk is sold to a Bolivian company that is well-known throughout the country. Natalia has a young daughter. Her husband went to work in Brazil and sends money home every month for the household expenses, but it is still not enough, so she engages in her business to earn extra income.

This loan will be invested in the construction of a wall in her house so that her family can live comfortably and experience a better quality of life. She is grateful to Emprender and Kiva for demonstrating their confidence in her by providing this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to build a wall in her house

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred F. is from the village of San Rafael. She is 23 years old and single. To make a living, Mildred owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Mildred has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells one of the animals she has raised.

In 2009, Mildred joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. Mildred is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the third loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Janet

texts.es: Janet  tiene 38 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos en una casa alquilada. Hace mas de 3 años, Janet y su esposo ofrecen el servicio de consultoría, en el cual consiste en realizar proyectos, como instalaciones de servicio de agua potable y alcantarillado en las diversas comunidades de su localidad. Su esposo es ingeniero de profesión, por lo que es una carta aval que garantiza el profesionalismo con que hacen su trabajo y eso les da ventaja a sus potenciales clientes que acudan para pedir su servicio. Durante todo este tiempo de trabajo ha visto las grandes ventajas en sus ganancias que ha decidido  mejorar las instalaciones de su pequeña oficina que ha implementado en su casa. Este es la segunda vez que tiene un crédito con MFP, por tanto asegura será muy responsable con sus pagos, además confía que este aporte lo ayudará en el progreso de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, invertirá en el tramite de renovación de licencia de su consultoría.
texts.en:
Janet is thirty-eight and lives with her husband and two children in a rented house. For more than three years, Janet and her husband have had a consulting business, in which they do projects like installing potable water services and sewage systems in different communities in their town. Her husband is an engineer by profession, a reference that guarantees the professionalism with which they carry out their work, and provides an advantage to potential customers who turn to them for their services. The entire time Janet has been in business she has enjoyed big profits such that she has decided to make improvements to the small office in her home. This is her second loan with MFP, so she's sure to be responsible with her payments, and she's confident the support will help her progress her business. She plans to use the loan to pay for the renewal process for her consulting license.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for the renewal process for her consulting business.

loans.name: Geovanny Javier

texts.es:
Geovanny de 34 años, vive en el Fortín de Guayaquil (zona periurbana, con caminos de tierra, lomas y montañas con una ecología en disolución). El tiene una papelería (llamada en Ecuador bazar). 

Empezó hace 12 años vendiendo lentes para una óptica, poco a poco con esfuerzo alcanzo a venderlos a almacenes. Pero como quería mas ingresos invirtió sus ahorros en papelería y compro vitrinas para tener su propio negocio. Trabaja desde las 06h00am hasta las 21h00pm todos los días. 

Para agrandar mas el negocio el quiere comprar con el préstamo cuadernos, y confites. En el futuro quiere terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
Geovanny is 34 years old and lives in Fortín de Guayaquil (a mountainous periuban area with dirt roads, hills, and a deteriorating ecosystem). He manages a stationery shop called “Ecuador Bazaar”.

Twelve years ago, Geovanny began selling eyeglasses for an optician. Over time and with some effort, he was able to distribute these items to stores. However, he wanted to generate more income, so he invested his savings in a stationery shop and bought display cabinets to start his own business. He works every day from 6am until 9pm.

To expand his business Geovanny will use his loan to buy notebooks and candy. In the future, he wants to finish the construction of his house.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase notebooks & candy

loans.name: Sharmila

texts.en:
This is 32 year-old Sharmila S..  She is married and has one child, aged 3.  In 2006, she established her small retail store. Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she supoorts her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from Patan BPW and used it to purchase additional inventory for her store.  In the future, Sharmila plans to continue purchasing inventory and use her profits to send her children to school.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.  Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins.  By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.  While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen. This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

loans.use: To purchase  inventory for her store

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion A. is from the village of Blanco, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old. Concepcion is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Concepcion owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Concepcion has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Concepcion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Concepcion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase breeding livestock. Concepcion is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Concepcion from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 35 years old, married with 5 children who are 3, 8, 10, 13 and 15 years old.  Christine owns a shop where she sells foodstuffs.  She has been in this business for one year and the hours of her business are from 6 am to 9 pm every day.

Although Christine has been in this business for one year, her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully.  Thus she needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  Once given this loan, Christine hopes that she will expand her business through purchasing more foodstuffs for sale which in turn will allow her to satisfy her customers and increase her profits.  With these profits, she will improve the living conditions of her family and start saving for the future.

loans.use: a variety of foodstuffs

loans.name: Neria Group

texts.en:
This photo was taken at the business of Caroline M., a member of the Grupo Neria. It is located in the state of Veracruz in Mexico. In the photo you can see the group around her snack business. She works selling snacks and food and began doing so 17 years ago. She is requesting the loan to purchase food materials and a grill for the snacks. Her customers consider her to be a happy and hardworking person. When requesting the loan she felt happy because she is going to help her business grow. In addition, she will invest in cosmetics sales, which is another business of hers. She is 41 years old and completed up through the third year of elementary school. She lives in a common-law marriage and has a total of 4 children (3 females and 1 male). She wants this loan to possibly purchase a grill and to be able to prepare her snacks faster. She also hopes to remodel her house to move her business there, because her sister currently allows her to use the entrance to her house for her business and also helps her in preparing her snacks.

Maricela Martina V. is the president of the group. She is 38 years old and studied up to high school. She is a single mother and has only one daughter. She works raising and selling pigs, which she began doing 5 years ago. She is requesting the loan for the purchase of pigs to raise and sell, and for feed to fatten them.

The group is made up of 14 members. The others are: Olimpia S., shoe sales Obdulia G., mole sales María del Carmen L., chicken sales Mónica R., milk sales Concepción M., shoe sales Soledad M., handicraft sales Teresa M., chicken sales María Fátima V., shoe sales Emilia D., cosmetics sales Carolina V., shoe sales Luminosa S., cosmetics sales María Crispina M., food sales

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in their businesses (possibly to purchase a grill and pigs, respectively)

loans.name: Rosa Elena

texts.es:
Rosa es una madre de familia de dos hijos, muy dedicada para lograr ayudar a su familia, junto a su esposo trabajan en zona franca siendo asistente de plancha.
Y ella operaria. Se trabaja mucho aunque el  salario sea bajo se esfuerzan para equilibrar los gastos.
Con ahorros y el primer financiamiento lograron cerrar su casa en mejores condiciones. 
Hoy en día con este préstamo invertirá en la compra de materiales de  construcción para terminar de cerrar el cuarto y comenzar la construcción del baño ya que aun no tiene la seguridad y privacidad para esta higiene necesaria de cada día. Comprara: piedra, arena, cemento, hierro, tubos de agua, para comenzar hacer la obra. Lo que está contenta,  por esta mejora que beneficiara a la familia en gran manera.
texts.en:
Rosa is the mother of two children. She is very dedicated to helping her family. She works along with her husband at the free trade zone. He is an ironing assistant and she is an operator. They work very hard and although their salary is low, they strive to balance their costs. With their savings and their first loan they were able to better wall off their house. With the current loan they will invest in the purchase of construction materials to finish the room walls and start building the bathroom. They still don't have the safety and privacy for their necessary daily hygiene. She will purchase stone, sand, cement, iron and water pipes to start construction. She is happy because this improvement will greatly help the whole family.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase stone, sand, cement, iron, water pipes to start construction.

loans.name: Anoncia

texts.en: Anoncia M. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 55 years old. Anoncia is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Anoncia runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Anoncia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2007, Anoncia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anoncia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Anoncia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Anoncia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Tania Gabriela

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Los Corrales se reúne cada 15 días en una localidad llamada Los Corrales a pocos minutos de Montecristi, ciudad con una rica cultura prehistórica, en este sitio la mayoría de los habitantes tiene diferentes actividades, tales como: artesanía.

La señora Tania tiene 19 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene un lindo bebe de un año y siete meses de nacido. Su marido es comerciante. Para ella este es su tercer ciclo en el Banco Comunal y está muy contenta ya que gracias a los créditos a podido ayudar a su marido con el negocio ya que es para el bien de ella y su familia.

El crédito que ella realiza es para el negocio de su esposo. Él se dedica a la compra y venta de tagua (producto que se utiliza para fabricar botones y otras muchas variedades de productos) él se desplaza hasta los campos  en otras ciudades donde consigue este producto más barato, los transporta hasta Manta donde las vende a comerciantes de allá que lo exportan a otros lugares. Trabaja de lunes a viernes desde las 6am hasta las 17h00.

Este crédito es para comprar más tagua ya que quiere aprovechar que está a muy buen precio en el mercado. Sus sueños son comprar una casa  ya que viven en la casa de sus suegros y también un carro.
texts.en:
The Los Corrales community bank meets every two weeks in a town called Los Corrales which is a few minutes from Montecristi, a city with a rich prehistoric culture.  The inhabitants of this town carry out a number of different business activities such as handicrafts and general commerce.

Tania is 19 years old and lives with her partner.  They have a beautiful 19 month-old baby.  Her husband is a merchant.  This is Tania's third loan cycle with the community bank and she is very happy since, thanks to the loans, she has been able to help her husband with his business which is for the good of her and her family.

The loan which she is requesting is for her husband's business.  He buys and sells 'tagua' (a type of 'vegetable ivory' which is used for making buttons and many other types of products).  He travels to the countryside where he can obtain the product cheaper, he transports it to Manta where he sells it to merchants who export it to other countries.  He works from Monday to Friday from 6.00am to 5.00pm.

This loan will be used to buy more 'tagua' since he wants to take advantage of the fact that it is selling for a good price in the market.  Tania's dreams are to buy a house, since she lives with her in-laws, and also to buy a car.

loans.use: To buy 'tagua' (vegetable ivory)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy provisions.

loans.name: Copo De Nieve Group

texts.es:
La Banca Comunal de Copo de Nieve está iniciando su segundo ciclo en el centro focal de Germán Busch. Esta banca comunal cuenta con la participación de nueve integrantes, las mismas que desembolsaran por segunda vez. Han renovado la mesa directiva y para este ciclo tiene como presidenta a la señora Claudia, como tesorera Vicente y como secretaria de actas a la señora Adriana. Los negocios de las señoras son diferentes, entre ellos tenemos: venta de comida, tienda de abarrotes, confección de ropa deportiva, contratista en confección, fabricación de alfombras, venta de carnes, venta de grutas, comerciante y venta de papa y chuño.
La señora presidenta es una mujer joven con bastante experiencia, ella comenta que antes estuvo en otro centro focal por 6 años  y que cambió de centro focal, porque cambio de domicilio.  Entusiasmada también comenta que fue ella quién formó este nuevo grupo, el mismo que hasta la fecha ha trabajado sin tropiezos. 
Con respecto a l negocio de la señora presidenta, ella costura ropa deportiva, aprendió de su mamá hace muchos años atrás. Ella compra los insumos para la elaboración de los deportivos de la Feria 16 de Julio y realiza sus ventas en las provincias aledañas a la ciudad de El Alto.
Lo que más le gusta de Pro Mujer es la oportunidad de reunirse con sus compañeras y olvidarse de las preocupaciones.
texts.en:
The Copo de Nieve village bank is beginning its second cycle in the German Busch center.  The village bank has 9 members who were all involved in the first cycle as well.  They have reunited the board and, for this cycle, Claudia is the president of the board, Vicente is the treasurer, and Adriana is the secretary.  Each of the women run different business such as selling food, grocery stores, making athletic wear, candy, rugs, selling meat, grutas, potatoes and potato flour.

The group president is a young woman with a lot of experience; she worked in another area for 6 years but moved her business to this shopping center when she moved. She formed this group of borrowers with a great degree of enthusiasm and to date, they have worked well together without any problems.  

The group president runs a business sewing athletic clothing; she learned the trade from her mother many years ago.  She buys the materials for the clothing in the 16 de Julio market and she sells the clothes in the small towns around the city of El Alto.  What she most likes about Pro Mujer is the opportunity to get together with her bank partners and forget her worries.

loans.use: Purchase an industrial sewing machine

loans.name: Josephine Wamaitha

texts.en:
Josephine has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 30 years.  She is 49 years old and is married to Joseph M.. They have five children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend. This will be her third loan. She paid all her previous loans well and in good time.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizer, potato seedlings and pay for labor.

In the future, Josephine hopes to buy more land so that she can practice large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, potato seedlings and pay for labor

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en:
Saturnina A. is from the village of Linconcomonan, Gingoog City. She is 52 years old. Saturnina is separated from her spouse and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling green bananas in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Saturnina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Saturnina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional green bananas to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more green bananas to sell.

loans.name: Lazarus Mungora

texts.en: Lazarus, who is 34 years old, married to Dorcas Wangui and the father of two children, has operated a motorcycle transport business in Naivasha town for the last two years.  He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend, and this will be his first loan which he will use to renew the insurance on his motorbike.  In the future, Lazarus hopes to grow his business and buy his own lorry.

loans.use: To renew insurance forhis motorbike.

loans.name: Imelda Yadao's Group

texts.en:
Imelda Y. is 49 years old and the leader of “Imelda Y.’s Group” a 10-member loan group from ASKI. She is from the village of Simmimbaan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Imelda is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Imelda owns and operates a business making and selling food. Her main source of income comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. 

Imelda joined ASKI in 2006 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. Imelda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to pay tuition fees of for her child.


About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and provide

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.es: Felicitas tiene 30 años, nacido en el distrito de San Miguel, convive con Cirilo de 33 años y tienen 05 hijos;  viven en su casa propia, en la comunidad de Palmapampa anexo del Distrito de Samugari. Felicitas y su esposo Cirilo, son el sostén de su familia. Ha Felicitas desde muy niña sus padres le inculcaron a trabajar en la chacra, hoy es campesina y cuenta con 03 hectáreas de terreno cultivados con plantas de achiote, cacao, hojas de coca y maní; que son plantas originarias de la zona selvática del Valle Río Apurimac. Viene trabajando 12 años en sus propias tierras y lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cosechar; ya durante ese tiempo necesita el apoyo de la mano ajena y tiene que contratar jornaleros para avanzar con las extracciones de los frutos, al final  siente que los meses de arduo trabajo le brindan como recompensa la calidad de sus frutos. Considera que lo más difícil es transportar sus productos desde la chacra hasta la ciudad de san francisco, lugar donde le ofrecen mejores precios por sus granos y hojas de coca. En adelante, desea comprar nuevas tierras para incrementar sus cultivos. Este su 11avo crédito de Felicitas con MFP, sabe que si lo paga a tiempo, podrá acceder a otro préstamo con mayor tranquilidad y sin traerle complicaciones a su banco comunal. Con los tres nuevos soles solicitados, comprará fertilizantes e insecticidas para mejorar sus plantaciones y así obtener buenos frutos.
texts.en:
Felicitas is 30 years old. She was born in the San Miguel district. She lives with her husband, Cirilo, who is 33, and they have five children. They live in their own house in the community of Palmapampa, which is an annex of the Samugari district. Felicitas and her husband Cirilo are the support of their family. From the time when Felicitas was a very young girl, her parents taught her to work on the farm. Now she is a farmer and has three hectares of land planted with achiote, cacao, coca leaves, and peanuts, which are plants that are native to the forest zone of the Apurimac River valley. She has been working her own land for 12 years, and the part she likes most is the harvest. During this time she needs the help of others, and she needs to hire day workers to make progress with the harvesting of her crops. At the end, she feels that the months of hard work have offered her repayment in the quality of her products. She finds that the most difficult part is transporting her products from the fields to the city of San Francisco, the place where they offer her better prices for her crops and coca leaves. In the future she wants to buy new land to increase her cultivation. 

This is her 11th loan with MFP, and she knows that if she pays it on time, she will be able to access another loan with great ease and without bringing complications to her community bank. With the 3000 PEN that she is applying for, she will buy fertilizers and insecticides to improve her plantings and thus obtain good crops.

loans.use: Comprar fertilizantes e insecticidas

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina is a member of this group loan. She is the mother of a son and a daughter. Both are young and getting their education. 

She is a housewife as well as a working woman. She is a very active and supportive lady who has been living in the city of Pakpattan for many years with her family. Pakpattan is a small city of Punjab province, known for its agriculture industry. She lives there in a two-room brick house.
 
She is a beautician who operates a beauty salon at her home and provides make-up facilities to her clients.
 
Her husband’s name is M. A. and he operates a grocery store in the market. Through his shop he sells daily use items such as cooking oil, sugar, lentils and spices. People prefer to buy from him because of the quality of his products and his good rates.
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband, who wants to put more groceries into his grocery store for its expansion. This will help him fulfill customer needs and earn better profits. He has been doing this business for five years and Sakina is hopeful that an investment will put his business in a more profitable position.
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

Note: In the photo, one of Sakina's loan members named Bushran is showing her sewing work.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery store business

loans.name: Tom

texts.en: Tom is 32 years old and married and with two children. He has a business making sun beds, chairs and tents to better his family’s living standards. He has been operating the business for six years. He has employed one person. He joined Faulu Kenya under the Unity Self Help group. Being a member of the group, he saves his money and is able to access loans from Faulu Kenya easily because the group members guarantee each other's loans.  He is asking for 40,000 KES to buy timber.

loans.use: To buy timber

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a married man with four children; two attend school while two are still too young for school. His wife is a shopkeeper and she contributes to the upbringing of their children. They live in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Stephen has operated a "boda boda" ( motorcycle) business for the past two years, villagers and travelers are his potential customers. In addition he also operates a retail shop business which contributes to his monthly income to meet his family demands. 

With the loan he is requesting, he wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour and maize flour, service his motorcycle, and put in electric sockets to start a mobile charging business. Stephen dreams of expanding his business even more in the future.

loans.use: To service his motorcycle, purchase bundles of wheat flour and maize flour, and put in electric sockets to start a mobile charging business.

loans.name: Twongere Umusaruro Group

texts.fr: Esdras Gakuru est agriculteur de mais, et client d’ACB depuis 2008.  Il a 48 ans, il est marie, ne au Rwanda, et il a 8 enfants entre 1 an et 25 ans.  Un de ses enfants va à l’école, et Esdras a fini 3 ans d’école poste-primaire.  Ce crédit est son premier cycle avec ACB, et il va utiliser son prêt pour acheter 5 kgs de mais, main d’œuvre, et location du champ.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est de cultiver les mais en augmentant l’espace de cultiver.  Il voudrait s’autofinancer, et aussi bâtir beaucoup de maisons d’habitation a louer pour augmenter ses revenus.
texts.en:
Esdras Gakuru is a corn farmer and has been a client of ACB since 2008. He is 48 years old and married. Born in Rwanda, he has eight children, aged 1 to 25. One of his children goes to school. Esdras has finished three years of post-primary schooling. 

This loan is his first cycle with ACB, and he is going to spend his loan on 5 kg of corn, manual labor, and leasing farm fields. His strategy for business growth is to grow corn by adding to his arable land. 

He would like to be self-financing and also to build many houses to rent out, so as to increase his revenues.

loans.use: Achat de 5 kgs de mais, main d'oeuvre, location du champ

loans.name: Famer De Jesús

texts.es:
Durante 14 años Famer V. ha vendido frutas en un semáforo ubicado en una de las autopistas de la ciudad de Medellín; allí tiene clientes fijos quienes se han encargado de posicionar sus ventas y generarle buenos ingresos. Este microempresario luchador ha trabajado toda su vida para sacar a adelante a sus 6 hijos. Inicialmente trabajaba en  la ciudad de Barranquilla en una empresa a la que renunció cuando decidió montar un bar en Jericó, Departamento de Antioquia; sin embargo el negocio quebró y Famer debió buscar otra forma de conseguir ingresos para sostener a su familia.
 
Actualmente Famer trabaja todos lo días de 6:00a.m. a 7:00 p.m. y aunque frecuentemente debe enfrentarse a las dificultades del invierno, se siente orgulloso por haber sacado a adelante su negocio el cual surte constantemente. Es por esto que Famer está buscando el capital con el que comprará la mercancía necesaria para ofrecer más y mejores frutas y así permitir que sus ventas aumenten. Espera en el futuro tener un kiosco fijo para establecer su negocio y así protegerlo de las lluvias.
texts.en:
Famer V. has been selling fruit for fourteen years at a stoplight on one of the highways in the city of Medellín.  He has fixed customers there who have placed orders, and this generates good earnings for him.

This tenacious small businessman has worked all of his life to get his six children ahead.  He started working for a company in Barranquilla.  He resigned when he decided to set up a bar in Jericó in the Antioquia department.  Nevertheless, the business failed, and Famer had to look for another way to get income to support his family.

Famer now works every day from 6:00 a.m. until 7:00 p.m.  Even though he frequently needs to confront the difficulties of the winter, he is proud.  This is because he has gotten his business, which he constantly stocks, ahead.  

That is why Famer is looking for capital to buy the merchandise needed to sell more and better fruits.  This will allow his sales to increase.  In the future he hopes to have a fixed kiosk in order to establish his business and protect it from the rains.

loans.use: to buy supplies

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira is 44 years old and married with two children.

Elvira works hard to provide for her family. She runs a business buying and selling ginger in the Philippines and requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of ginger to sell.

Elvira has borrowed and paid back 11 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the buying and selling of ginger business for four years and earns additional income from her general store.

Elvira aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional ginger  to sell

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Life couldn't be called life at all when one doesn't live it to the fullest. Lilibeth, 46, realizes this truth and makes sure she and her family live their lives at the maximum. She finished only the first year in high school. At present, she works hard in business to make up for what she lacks in education. Her husband Policarpio, a vendor, works hard too. They have two children, one of whom is already working, while the younger one studies in college.  Together, they live in Parola Area, Binondo, Manila.

Lilibeth manages her own sari-sari (variety) store. Here, she sells daily household essentials and sells rice in retail. Lilibeth also raises hogs for a living.  These businesses are all managed and operated near their home. Lilibeth has worked these businesses for 12 years now. With the help of one delivery boy, she makes around Php1, 000 net income daily.

To help her improve her business, Lilibeth applies for a Php26, 000 loan. She will use this money to purchase additional grocery items for her store.  She will also purchase at least four hogs for slaughter and sell. Lilibeth says that this loan will definitely increase her capacity to earn. With the incoming profits, she plans to allocate funds to what is needed in her business: materials needed for hog raising, replenishment of stocks in her store, and more. She also plans to avail herself of government services for health and insurance to keep her and her family in good shape.

Like many micro-entrepreneurs, Lilibeth also has her share of periods of low sales, especially during summertime when people go out of town or prefer to stay home all day. But still she refuses to settle for anything less than a life lived to the fullest. She desires to achieve success in business and see that her children will also become successful. Lilibeth hopes to have a vacation in their home province in Cebu.  As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her store and to purchase at least four pigs for slaughter and sell their meat.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is 28 years old.  She is married and has 4 children, 2 of them go to school.  Rose sells bread to earn income.  She borrowed a loan to stock more bread to sell.  She hopes to expand her business in the future with the extra profits.

loans.use: stock more bread to sell

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es: El señor Manuel es director de música en un grupo de música tropical. El crédito lo requiere para la compra de un órgano sintetizador, una guitarra electrica para renovar sus aparatos, pues se encuentra en proceso de  grabación de nuevos temas musicales. Vive en alquiler vive en la zona 12 de octubre en la ciudad de La Paz; es casado y tiene un hijo. Es primer crédito con IMPRO y KIVA.
texts.en:
Manuel is musical director of a tropical music band.  He needs the loan to buy a synthesizing organ and an electric guitar to renovate his instruments because he’s in the process of recording new musical numbers.

He rents his house in the city of La Paz’s 12 de Octubre zone.  He’s married and has a son.  This is his first loan with IMPRO and Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a pair of musical instruments for the band he leads.

loans.name: 18 Đông Sơn Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Mận has a retail business selling dry food. She is requesting a loan to invest in her business.

Mận is 53 years old and she is married with two children. She is the leader of a 4-member group, the 18 Đông Sơn  solidarity group. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents.

This is Mận's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women. Mận has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Mận faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Mận hopes for her children to find a good job, for her business to do well, and to buy a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase more food to resell.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 58 years old, married and has two children. Mohamad has owned a coffee shop since 1980. He inherited this business from his parent, so he has a deep understanding of local consumer needs and he is well known in his area.

Mohamad is requesting a $3000 loan to buy new furniture and a large television screen for his shop. He is aiming to gain more profit so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to buy new furniture and a large television screen for his shop.

loans.name: Maria's Communal Bank Group

texts.en:
Maria Gregoria is the president of this communal bank comprised of six women and one man. The members of the communal bank live and work near the city of Ambato in the central Ecuadorian Andes. 

Maria Gregoria is 32 years old and married. She lives with her husband and their two sons, aged eight and six years. She is a dedicated and collaborative person. Maria Gregoria buys and raises cattle. She began her business three years ago when she bought a calf. Afterwards, she invested in a milk cow. She currently works with her husband. 

This loan is Maria Gregoria’s first and she will invest the money in a new cow. She hopes that this loan will improve the income for her family. Maria Gregoria’s goal for the future is that her family will be able to continue the business and expand it to include selling milk and cheese. 

All of the women in the photo and the man in the red hat are the borrowers. The additional men are the husbands of some of the women.

loans.use: to purchase a new cow.

loans.name: Akossiwoa

texts.fr:
Akossiwoa est une femme âgée de 44 ans. Elle est mariée å un maintenancier. Elle a 02 enfants. 
Akossiwoa travaille comme revendeuse de pagnes  depuis 2008. Elle coud elle-même les habits et revend à ses clients à ADAWLATO. Elle achète les produits à LOME. Elle travaille avec 02 employé(e)s. 
Akossiwoa a requis son premier cycle de prêt à WAGES afin d’acheter des pagnes.
texts.en: Akossiwoa is a 44-year-old woman who is married to a maintenance technician. She has two children. She has been working as a retailer of pagnes (colorful West African cloth) since 2008.
